cell.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

For rates, dates of sailing, and further particulars

div.head: Orient-Royal Mail Line.
div.p: OUTWARD to AUSTRALIA.
R.M.S. "Ormus" will leave Suez about December 27
R.M.S "Oruba" will leave Suez about January 9.
HOMEWARD to NAPLES, MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY.
R.M.S. "Oroya" will leave Port Said about December 30
R.M.S. "Ophir" will leave Port Said January 13

The issue of return tickets to and from Egypt has been discontinued. Passengers paying full fare one direction will, however, be allowed abatement of one-third off fare back if return voyage be made within four months of arrival, or abatement of 20 o/o if return voyage be made within six months of arrival.
Special reduced rates during Summer season.
Agents, Cairo: Thomas Cook & Son, Ltd. ; Alexandria : R. J. Moss & Co.
For all imformation apply to Wm. STAPLEDON & Sons, PORT SAID and PORT-TEWFIK (Suez). 31-12-6

div.head: BIBBY LINE MAIL TWIN-SCREW STEAMERS.
div.p: OUTWARDS to COLOMBO, TUTICORIN, etc., and RANGOON.
S.S. Staffordshire 5,775 tons, will leave Suez about December 23.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON.
S.S. Cheshire 7,182, will leave Port Said about December 19.
Fares from Port Said to Marseilles £12.0.0 ; London £17.0.0 ; Colombo £32.10.0 ; Rangood £37.10.0
Fitted with Refigerators, Electric Light, Electric Fans and all recent improvements.
SPECIAL REDUCED FARES DURING THE SUMMER SEASON. 12-931
Agents in Cairo: THOS. COOK & SON. For all particulars apply to WM. STAPLEDON & SONS PORT SAID PORT TEWFIK (Suez).

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Shortest, calmest, most beautiful sea passage to Europe. Express steamers leave Alexandria 4 p.m. every Wednesday for Pireus. (Athens), Smyrne, Mitylene, Constantinople, in connection with Orient Express luxe train for Sofia, Belgrade, Budapest, Vienna, Paris, London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 5 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
SUDAN EXPRESS MAIL SERVICE.

KKHARTOUM in 3 days. Express steamers leave Suez Docks 5 p.m. every Wednesday for Port Sudan (and Suankin) in connection with Sudan Government Railways Express Luxe Service to Khartoum, arriving 8 p.m. Saturdays.
Steamers from Suez 5 p.m. every Monday evening for Jedda, calling one week at Tor, El-Wedj; Yambo, Jedda; and the following week at Tor, Yambo, Jedda, Port Sudan, Suakim, Massowah, Hodeida, Aden.
For frieght or passagee apply the Co.'s Agencies Alexandria, Port Said, Suez, Cairo; or for passages only to Thos. Cook & Soy, Hamburg- Amerika Linie, Reisse Burrati or other Tourist Agencies.

div.head: Deutsche Levante-Linie.
div.p: Mail and Passenger Steamships. Regular fortnightly Service from HAMBURG; weekly from ANTWERP; every 4 weeks from Bordeaux direct to ALEXANDRIA for Rotterdam and Hamburg. Goods forwarded at through- rates from all German Railway Stations on direct Bills of Lading to ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO, SYRIA, ETC. Special facilities for conveyance of cotton, etc from Alexandria via Rotterdam and Hamburg to German manufacturing towns. For tarift and particulars apply to Adolphe Stross. Alexandria Agent- The following are expected at Alexandria: Dec 21 S.S "Hythnos", from Antwerp -Dec. 22 S.S "Pyrgos" from Hamburg - Dec 23 S.S. "Royal" from Hamburg.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Philae now on the berth, will sail on or about Monday, December 16, to be followed by S.S. Monepthah.s.
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.
Passenger Tickets also issued inclusive of Railway fare through to and from Cairo. Particulars apply R. J MOSS & CO. ALEXANDRIA AGENTS
R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

div.head: P. HENDERSON & CO's LINE.
div.p: Steamers leave SUEZ and PORT SAID fortnightly for LONDON and Algiers or LIVERPOOL direct.
(Electric Light.) SALOON (Amidships) FARE £12. (Latest improvements.)
S.S. AVA 7100 Tons bruthen, will leave Port Said about Dec. 7th for Hamburg, and Glasgow landing U.K. passengers Devonport.
S.S. MARTABAN 5600 Tons will leave Alexandria about December the 23rd, for London, Liverpool and Glasgow.
Due in LONDON or LIVERPOOL 13 days thereafter.
The Saloon accommodation is amidships, and the vessels are fitted throughout with Electri Light, and have all the latest improvements.
For furthur information apply to the Company's Agents.
Apply WORMS & Co., Port Said and Suez. THOS. COOK & SON, (EGYPT) LD., CAIRO ;
G. J. GRACE & CO., ALEXANDRIA.

div.head: SUDAN DEVELOPMENT & EXPLORATION COMPANY, LIMITED
div.p: KHARTOUM: CAIRO Office, Sharia Kasr-el-Nil.

TRANSPORT DEPARTMENT. Six days White Nile Tourist Trip dep. Khartoum Tuesdays. Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at all Cairo Tourist Agents. - Special Steamers for private charter. - Trips arranged and transport of goods undertaken to all places on White and Blue Niles within navigation limits.

ENGINEERING DEPARTMENT. Shipyard for construction of sternwheel steamers, barges, stream, motor launches, etc. Contractors for supply and erection of all classes of machinery, buildings, irrigation pumps, etc.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum.-Moderate fares.
Specially Reduced Rates for residents of Egypt by Tourist Services during November and December. First sailing November 13th.
WEEKLY FREIGHT SERVICE FROM CAIRO TO ASSUAN AND HALFA.
Cook's Interpreters in uniform are present at principal Railway Stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their tickets.
Special Steamers and Dahabeahs for private parties.
Special arrangements for tour in PALESTINE, SYRIA and the DESERT; Lowest rates.
Best camp equipment in the country.

Deposit Accounts opened at sight & for fixed periods, Advances on securities, in current account. Letters of Credit and Telegraphic Transfers Issued. Foreign Exhange Bought and Sold. div.head: CREDIT LYONNAIS
div.p: CAPITAL FRANCS 250,000,000 ENTIEREMENT VERSES
Agences d'Egypte : ALEXANDRIE, LE CAIRE, PORT-SAID.

Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que : Avances sur titres fixes et en compte courant, Avances sur marchandises et consignations, Emission de traités et chèques, Emission de lettres de Crédit, Paiements par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France èt de l'étranger, Garde de titres Recouvrement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger ; le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds en compte de depôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe au taux de 3 o/o pour 1 an et au-delà. 31-12-906

Patras, Yolo, Syra, Calamata. The Bank undertakes all banking business in Egypt, Greece, etc. Interests on cash deposits,
3 0/0 per ann. at sight; 3 1/2 0/0 per ann. for 6 months; 4 0/0 per ann. for 12 months; 5 0/0 per ann. for 3 years and over. Savings

div.p: Capital: £3,000,000. RESERVE (Environ) : £1,500,000. MR. F. T. ROWLATT, Governor

La National Bank of Egypt reçoit des dépots à termes fixes, fait des avances et ouvre des comptes courants sur titres, valeurs et marchandises. Elle s'occupe de l'achat et de la vente d'effets sur l'Etranger, de l'escompte, ainsi que de toutes opérations de Banque. 31-12-906

div.head: CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN
div.p: Capital 12,500,000 Francs entièrement verses. — Agence d'Alexandrie, 14, Rue Stamboul.

LE CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN fait toutes opérations de Banque, notamment: Escompte d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'etranger. Avance sur titres.—Garde de titres.—Depots de fonds a vue et à échéance fixe avec intérêts aux taux suivants: 2 1/2 0/0 pour dépôts de 6 mois, 3 0/0 pour dépôts d'un an, 3 1/2 0/0 pour dépôts au délà d'un an. — LE CREDIT FRANCO-EGYPTIEN reçoit des Marchandises en consignation pour la vente et fait des Avances sur Cotons, Grains et autres marchandises. — 2833781-3-908

div.p: CAIRO.

The Banque du Caire Ltd., undertakes all banking business such as : Advances on deeds and securites, discount, cheques delivered at very best rates of exchange on all the principal towns of the world, telegraphic transfers, purchase and sale of stock and shares in Egypt and abroad, letters of credit issued, safe custoday at a low charge, of titles, deeds and securities, current accounts opened. Receives money on deposit at sight at 3% per annum.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd's Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice Trieste. Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria Saturdays 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi Tuesdays 5 a.m. in time for Express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival at Venice Wednesday about 9.30 a.m. Passengers may proceed from Venice to Switzerland, Paris and London by the 2 p.m. and 11.5 p.m. – Expresses. Arrival at Trieste Wednesday about 3 p.m. in connection with the Train de Luxe proceeding the same evening to Vienna, Frankfort, Cologne, Brussel, Ostende and London. Arrival at London every Friday 5.12 p.m.
Special Train Service from Cairo Station to Alexandria Quay alongside steamer, Saturdays at 9.30 a.m.
Steamer leaves Alexandria every Thursday 4 p.m.

div.head: Hotel Beau-Rivage.
div.p: Ramleh – most charming Seaside Residence in Egypt
15 Minutes by Carriage or "Palais" tram from Sidi Gaber Station.
First Class Family Hotel with Every Modern Comfort. Unique Situation on the Beach.
Lovely Garden. Lawn Tennis. Large Terrace. Electric Light. Own springs. Perfect sanitary arrangements. Stables for horses and carriages.
Moderate Charges. -- Special terms for Government Officials and Officers of the Army of Occupation.
Telegraphic Address: BEAURIVAGE, Ramleh. – Telephone: 186, Ramleh. G. & M. RUNCKEWITZ, Proprietor.

div.head: Tewfik Palace Hotel.
div.p: Helouan, near Cairo.

Ideal English winter home. Moderate terms. Healthy situation. Lovely Gardens. Electric Light throughout. Perfect Sanitation. Pension Terms for Dec. and Jan. per day : Board- residence, Ss. 6d. ground floor( 10s, 6d including electric light and morning baths). 10s 6d. other floors(12s 6d including electric, morning bath, afternoon tes.) Double rooms allowed 5% discount. For fed., March, April, 2s and 4s. extra according to room.
For particulars. Apply Manager or Stephenson & Co., Opera Square, Cairo

div.head: Semiramis Hotel
div.p: The first small dance of the season at the Semiramis Hotel, Cairo, will be held to-morrow evening, commencing at 10 p.m.

div.head: Suez Post Office.
div.p: Mr. Paul Garofallo has arrived at Suez, aid ' taken over his post, as Post-Master, succeeding Mr. Harrington who has been transferred to Port Said.

div.head: Austrian Lioyd Almanac.
div.p: We have received from the. Austrian Lloyd Company, Trieste, a most attractively and artistically designed almanac for the year 1908.

div.head: Egyptian Mail 8.8. Co.
div.p: The Egyptian Mail Steamship Company has ats arrangements for booking in advance passengers' baggage from London to Alexan- dria and Cairo.

div.head: Al Hayat Sanatorium.
div.p: The Al Hayat orchestra, composed of fifteen . first class musicians, has arrived at Helovan 'and will play on the terrace of the Sanatorium from 3.30 to 6 p.m. every Sunday, Monday, Wednesday, and Friday.

div.head: Bubonic Plague.
div.p: Two more patients suffering from plague have been admitted to hospital during 'the «last 24 hours, and the number under treat- ment is at present 19. 1229 cases have been under treatment throughout Egypt from the ist January to the 16th December, and 892 of these have proved fatal.

div.head: Societe des Publications Egyptiennes.
div.p: Schuler's Library, at Alexandria, has receiv- ed a consignment of an interesting English work on architecture, entitled "Flats, Urban. Houses, and Cottage Homes," (Hodder and Stoughton, publishers ; London) This volume is beautifully illustrated-and would be of use to architects in this country for its very complete plans of the latest internal arrangements of London and Parisian flats.

div.head: Sirdar's Motor-Car.
div.p: A rew motor-car has been completed for Sir Francis Wingate, Sirdar of Egypt, by the New Arrol- Johnston Company. The engine, of 45 hp. nominally, but capable of higher power, is cased in sheet metal to be sandproof. The wheels are of cast steel, with discs of shee steel bolted on. to each side, and are fitted with 'solid tyres. Paddle blades are bolted to the driving wheels for assistance in driving through soft. sand. The rubber tyres have narrower threads than usual to permit of sinking 1 in the 'sand, as the wide, flat tyres first used in sand tended to churn up & bank in front, but the new tyre ainks to the hard, This is the. second car built, by the New Arrol-Johnston Company ~ for the Sirdar.

div.head: Sallors and Soldiers' Institute.
div.p: The fancy sale and 'Christinas tree of the Sailors and Soldiers; [natitute will be held at the Institade next Friday, commencing at 3 p.m, Entrance tothe Sale will be P.T. 3 and to the Christmas tree, which will include 360 prizes, P.T. 5, T he following ladies have kindly consented to take stalls; —Miss Hilda Lang Anderson, Mrs. Neville Borton, Miss Garnett Botfield, Miss: Gertrude Carver, Miss Beatrice Davis, Miss Mafy Davis, Mrs Stanley Gordon, PhéHonble Mrs Hopkinson, Mrs. P.H. King- ham, Mrs.' Morrison, Mrs, Hicks Paull, Mrs, "Banwell: Rees, Mrs, Algernon Ward, and others. By kind permission of C olonel R.C.C. Cox and Officers, the String Band of the 2nd Batt. Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers will play during the afternoon.

div.head: The Rise in House Rent.
div.p: The excessive and continuons rise in honse rent in Alexandria and Cairo, in the face of an acute financial crisis, is one of the economic mysteries of Egypt. The same sort of thing has of late been going on at Naples - where the inhabitants have adopted a drastic method of solving the difficulty. Naples is.in the throes of something very closely resembling civil war owing to the rise of house-rent, which has been artificially pnt up by a syndicate of builders. Nearly 6,000 people have refused not only to pay their rent, but even to leave their houses, and the number of these passive resisters is so large that it is. impossible to dislodge them. Now the authorities have decided to evict them by force. The garrison has been reinforced hy 500 soldiers, 1,000 carabiniers, and 250 police men, to meet all possible emergencits.

div.head: German Levant Line.
div.p: Towards nine p m. on Friday week the German Levarit Line's S.S. "Milos," of Hamburg, was signalled in distress and on fire five miles westward of Ushant Light. The Maritime Pre- fecture immediately ordered Torpedo-boat 170 to proceed to the assistance of the "Milos," and three steamers and several fishing-boats also went to help her. Eight men belonging to the crew were still on board, but twelve others had taken to a boat, and nothing has since been seen of them. On the following day, north of Moléme, the Hull steamer "Douro" tovk the "Milos" in tow, with the object of bringing her to Brest; but after encountering serious difficulties was compelled to relinquish the attempt, the tow rope having been burned. It is feared that the "Milos," before she can be towed into safety, will run upon the rocks and become a total wreck. Lifeboats have gone in search of the twelve missing sailors, but it is feared that they have perished.

div.head: EGYPT AND ERYTHREA
div.p: AN INTERESTING COMPARISON.
LORD CROMER'S POLICY.
(Gazette's Special Service).

London, Tuesday. The former Roman Deputy. Signor Ostini, in the last number of the "Rivista Coloniale," makes an. interesting comparison between England in Egypt and Italy in Erythrea. He holds up Lord Cromer's administration to the admiration of his own countrymen, stating that Lord Cromer's foremost aim was to gain the confidences of the native population, and he eulogised his great public works in the protection of the small native proprietor against the foreign capitalist, and his financial policy. He further remarks that in less than a quarter of a century Egypt has passed from bank- ruptcy to a state of prosperity such as no other purely agricultural country of the old world has attained. He proceeds to point oat to public opinion that Italy still regards the Red Sea colony with suspicion, due to the errors and disasters of the past. Yet, under the | ministration of the late Governor Martini, Erythrea had made considerable progress, and would have made more if they had'been backed up at home

div.head: SUPREME CONSULAR COURT.
div.p: REX v. CANNON.

The last case to be heard at the Alexandria sessions of the Supreme Consular Court came on for hearing this morning. It is of interest as it is the first case of the trial of an English- man for the murder of another Englishman that has come before the Cons" larCoart within. living memory. Mr. Whitworth was counsel. for the accused, Thomas Cannon, who has been in Hadra Prison since the 24th October, when he was arrested by Mr. Blattner, the Superintendent of the Port City Police at Alexandria. The prosecution was conducted by Mr. Preston, the Crown Prosecutor for Egypt.

The crime was committed on board a petroleum steamer, the 'Baku Standard" at Alexandria at about 1 a.m. on the 24th October last. Cannon cut the throat of a fellow fireman, named Henry King, who on his return to England was to have married. The Captain and several officers of the S.S. "Baku Standard" arrived on the 10th inst. from England by the S.S. "Heliopolis" in order to attend the trial. Several fireman belonging to the same steamer have been detained at the Sailors' Home at Alexandria since the crime in order to give evidence before the Court.

div.head: EXHIBITION OF PAINTINGS.
div.p: Miss Janet Lewis has returned for her se: cond winter in Cairo, and is already exhibit- ing a few of her charming sketches in the salon of M. Zola, the well-known photographer, in Sharia Manakh. Miss Lewis has had the. advantage of a thorough training in art, for after her early education at South Kensington she spent three years of real hard work in Paris, where she studied under Jean Paul Laurem the late Benjamin Constant and other well known masters. Shé has studied in Holland, and has done good work in the best studies, and has exhibited in the Paris salon. Her sketches are but few in number, but they show real signs of c'everness and originality. They ate spontaneous in expression and good in colouring, and Miss Lewis has a very happy faculty for reproducing those clean, soft effects which cast so much aglamour over Egyptian scenes. Very noticeable in this respect is the sketch of the sheikh's Tomb at Old Cairo, altogether an admirable bit of work, and the clean fresh treatment of the river bank of Ghizeh is also well worth mention.: The series entitled "The Wayside Restaurant," "Pickle | shop," and "Drapers shop" showmore ambitious composition, but they are very ,happily con- ceived and are executed with nite judgment of detail and colour. The most important of these sketches on show is that ofa street in Old Cairo, somewhat sombre m tone, but very able in its treatment. Miss Lewis is collecting material for a small exhibition in Piccadilly next spring, but prices are attached to her sketches now on view which should do much to make them popular. Miss Lewis is also a miniature painter of considerable suoces and is prepared to undertake portraits from photographs or personal sittings while she is in Cairo

div.head: NILE VALLEY (NEW) CO.'S OPERATIONS.
div.p: Messrs. Lake and Currie, the company's engineers, report as follows ;— Development— The "D" level south has advanced 5 ft., making a total distance of 103 ft. from the main shaft vrosseut. Driving in this level was stopped on 3rd October. Wince C.8. 2 has been started at a distance of 45 ft. north from No, 1 shaft, and at the end of the month had been sank to a depth of 20 ft. below ''C" level. The reef carries an average value of 4.1 dwts per ton over an average width of 40.5 ins (The portion of this winze sunk during the present month shows an improvement in both the value and width of the reef.) Stoping—The ore stoped during - month amounted to 710.9 .tons,° this being obtained from the C and D blocks. Mil ling—During ethe month the 10- -stampt mill treated 1,100 tons of ore, which yielded 299,446 ozs fine gold, exclusive of 2 tons of concontrates, having an assay value of 28 dwts per ton,

div.head: THE ZOOLOGICAL SOCIETY
LORD CROMER ELECTED FELLOW.
div.p: (Gazotto's Spoolal Servio..)
London, Tuesday. Lord Cromer is to be elected a Fellow of the Zoological Society at the meeting to be held on Thursday..

div.head: L'AFRICAINE
div.p: "L'Africaine" was the first intimation of failure in the company, not so much from Mlle | Robertson's unfortunate errors in the septet, but from the apparent inability of anyone to put her right, and save the situation. Mlle Robertson-one cannot escape from the factsang very badly, and was hopelessly out of tune, but she should never have had the part, and she gave the impression that she disliked it. She should not be judged by it. · I cannot agree with the opinion of those who praised Mme Magne and M. Soubeyran true, Mme Magne was as correct as usual, but except for a moment or two in the second act, I. she was by no means impressive ; M. Soubeyran, in his more forceful moments displayed compass and tone, but in the 'piano' passages he was practically inaudible; no doubta critio in one of the first five rows may have heard and esteemed certain shades of expression inandible to those in the last rows of the stalls. Certainly some of the praises I read earned a seat in high places ! M. Valette was admirable in the 'Batlade' and deserved his encore, but for the rest he was less impressive than usual. M. Coiglio, as Don Pedro, was praised, but he seemed to me,-1 must confess it-timeless, crude, and devoid of vigour I notice that his good acting is mentioned ; perhaps the characteristics I mention ed suit the part of the nervous commander of an ill fated expedition. The chorus was again really excellent, instinct with decision, force, and accuracy, far more so than the orchestra ; and some of the voices seemed unusually good. | Indeed it seems as though the chorus this
year will prove the main stay of the operatic season ; except for M. Valette and Mlle Gene
vois (in her special parts) the promise is not | phenomenal-good, correct as a rule, free from

the harrowing discords of last year, but distinctly provincial. I anticipate Don Juan and, Lohengrin with mixed 'feetings. Of course L'Africaine' is not the opera one would choose to show off the best points of a company ; it is long pretentious, and uninteresting except for a few places, and eveu these seem inappropriate;
it is distinctly Mid-Viotorian and to carry it off | the soloists must be super-excellent. Still we
can take comfort in that the 'toughest pièces de rexistance' are being worked off early; we have better things in prospect.

div.head: TRAVIATA.
div.p: Yet another: excellent piece of work was "Traviata," and in many respects far more suited to the company, than the pieces they have so far given, (though it is not the first performance of "Traviata" by this company). | Mlle. Genevois has a most charming voice, clear, flexible, rather full for a light soprano, with certain very telling intonations in the middlo register. Her singing in the second act was all that could be hoped for. Mr. Flachat, when roused to efforts of passion or delicasy, is also most pleasing. At his best he should be really delightful : he was not always definite, and seemed to hesitate over his effects at times. M. Gorins, as the father, sang with great truth but rather too much sustained vigour. The chorus was as before, unusually good. What a reliet it is see nice costumes ; "talou rouge", periwigs and all the aceessories are each an improvement on the Mid-Victorian costume now again adopted in "Traviata."

div.head: EGYPTIAN COMPANIES UNDER ENGLISH LAW
div.p: To The EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE." | Sir, -The Supreme British Court in Egypt

having decided that the retention of share: certificates by the Bourse and Banking Com. pany from shareholders who refused any but "clean" certificates was an illegal act, and the Committee of the Bourse, having by a retro spective resolution, refused settlement on all | but these illegal certifioates, an interesting question arises whether this Committee have in any way made themselves liable for their complaisance. Offering you my congratulations on your snccessful efforts to vindicate English | law against foreign directors and to bell thecat.
Yours, &c.,
A. A. B. Alexandria, December 16.

div.head: EGYPTIAN CONSTRUCTIONS LIMITED.
div.p: To The Editor OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE."
Dear Sir, --It has been brought to my notioe that in a recent issue you stated I was a Director of the Egyptian Constructions, I beg to inform you that this is incorrect.
Yours faithfully,
MONTAGU SUMMERS. Cairo, December 16.
We only stated that Mr. Montagu Summers was one of the original directors of the Company, which was correct. Ed. E. G)
Hotel Casino San Stefano

p.hi: will be open during Winter. REDUCED PRICES

div.head: EGYPTIAN POLITICS
div.p: NATIONALISM AND JUSTICE.

The recent Press Case at Cairo has bad a deplorable effect on Europeans in Egypt, as the decision of the Court was generally recognised to have not been free from politieal influences. The latest issue of the "African World" contains an instructive analysis of the case by a Cairo correspondent, from which we extract the following :

Justice was dominated by political passion, the judge being a Nationalist, while the accused journalists were Syrians and Copts well known as ardent Anglophiles, and therefore hated by the more fanatical of the Egyptian Nationalists. Not only was the sentence severe, bat, it afforded an opportunity for rejoicings on the part of the Nationalists, who gave a banquet in honour of the judge, at which function, I am reliably informed, 'Temarkable toasts were drunk to the over-throw of the Oecupation l' Hence the Nationalists Press, sotnated by the same hatred and the same fealiogu of joy, took advantage of the occasion. to publish the text of the judgment 'in extenso', as well as a French translation thereof, which was designedly inaccurate.

The above-mentioned facts show & deplorable state of affairs. First, the liberty of the Press, which, according to Lord Cromer, is in Egypt "a guarantee that no abuse of authority shall pass unnoticed," has been rudely shaken by a judgment which will render henceforth impossible the publication of any criticism opon, or information unfavourable to, public functionaries—& state of things that appro aches to the Oriental conceptions of freedom of conscience and publie opinion.

These journalists did not merely seek to incriminate a police official. By mentioning, one in particular they endeavoured 'to draw public attention to certain abuses that were suspected. But, as I have already said, the principal evil is not the technical wrongs and errors coinmitted by the Pressmen. Generous principles are more to be considered : "the liberty of the Press and the liberty of native justice. In this connection it may be per-1. missible to quote the Comte de Collato, a doctor of laws, who has devoted a pamphlet to the case :- "The first quality of a people that aspires to self-government is to know how to render justice even to its adversaries. For the work ing of all other branches of the public administration the Occupation is in reality rezponsible. The law courts are autonomous. Therein three natives freely exercise, according to their consciences, full power as to the lives and property of their fellow-countrymen. These tribunals, therefore, constitute a permanent attempt at self-government. If the Egyptians show themselves incapable of rendering justice without prejudice, how shall they claim the right to levy and disburse taxes, to regulate the franchise, to administer the property of the State, etc. ?"

It is quite certain that since this affair mistrust of the Egyptian magistracy has penetrated into the European colonies. We have evidence to show that the foreign diplomatic agents have informed their respective Governments concerning this new difficulty which has suddenly sprung up in the way of Reform of the Capitolations in Egypt. More substantial guarantees will be demanded by the colonies, for the abandonment of their penal immunity The unknown factor in the Reform will'not be the police alone. The introduction proposed by Lord Cromer-of a Habeas Corpus Act into the penal legislation as to Europeans in Egypt seems no longer sufficient to guarantee the colonies against abuse of power by politician judges. And the net result of the affair is to postpone the coming of self-government in Egypt, a postponement for which the Nationalists are entirely responsible.

div.head: PRO CALABRIA.
THIS EVENING'S BENEFIT.
div.p: As our readers are aware the performance of the "Geisha" by the Lirica Lilliputian troupe is for the benefit of the victims of the recent Calabrian earthquakes, and will be given | under the patronage of the Governor of Alex. andria and the Consul General of Italy. That the theatre will be crowded is assured by the bookings, which already nearly fill the theatre, and we would join with the Committee in asking those ladies who will be present not to wear large hats. The troupe consists of children from 8 to 17 years of age and a large hat may well prevent anyone seeing anything at all.

div.head: CAIRO'S NEW BREWERY.
div.p: The plant of the brewery at Shubra, be| longing to the British Beer Breweries (Egypt) | Limited, is now installed and brewing will

begin in about fortnigbt. Mr. Desenn, the | Director of the Banque du Caire, has joined the | board of directors of this company. Mr. Gerala Girdwood, the managing Director of the Company, informe us that the future prospects of the company are all that can be desired and that the shares are saleable, a number having been sold in Cairo on Friday last for caslr The directors of the company get no fees or salaries and will get none until the shareholders are I paid a dividend, as they have so much conAdenge in the future of this conoern.

div.head: GOLD RETURNS
div.p: The imports of gold last week totalled L.E. 191,886, and the exports L.E. 4.710; | both these totals include Post Office specie.

div.head: LORD CROMER TESTIMONIAL FUND.
APPROVAL OF SCHOLARSHIP.
div.p: In response to the circular, dated 11th inst. issued by the Committee of the Lord Cromer Testimonial Fönd, which appeared in our issue of the 13th, the public meeting was held by the coprteons permission of the British Club at their commodiogs premises in the Boulevard de Ramleh, at 4.p.m. yesterday, Mr. R.J. Mong in the chair and the fall Committee, namely, Messrs. H. P. Kingham, V.F. Naggiar, Judge Lionel Sandars and W.T. Smith, being present.

There was a fair attendance of the British Community, including the Consal-General, Mr. E.B. Gould, 1.8.0. Messrs. P.W. Carver, W.P. | Chataway, JE. Cornish, CMG., JP. Jones, I Hickie, Moffat, H B.C. and F.W. Moss, etc., etc. Admiral Blomfield, G B. Williams, W.F. Sarjeant, Ambrose Ralli, K. and P. Birley, were, unfortunately unable to attend the meeting.

The minutes of the last Meeting, held on the 9th inst., at the Union Club, having been read and approved and notes from Messrs. Chataway, Kingham, and Lina, the Headmaster. I of the Victoria College, having also been read, and appreciated, it was decided to adopt Judge Sandars' proposal that the testimonial should take the form of an annual prize or soholarship, to be competed for by the pupils of Victoria, College, irrespective of nationality, to be drawn up on lines to be agreed upon later, after consultation with the Headmaster. Mr. J. P. Jones, on behalf of Messrs. Choremi Benachi and Co., informed the meeting of Mr. Benachi's generous offer to make a handsome donation provided the amount raised be snfficient to do full justice to the prize or scholarship.
A vote of thanks to the Chairman of Committee, duly acknowledged by him, closed the proceedings
As already stated we need not too strongly impress upon par fellow subjects the desirability of making their subscriptions at an early date.

Mr. Moss requests us to state that any Britisber who has not received the circular of the 11th inst., will obtain fall information on applying at the offices of Messrs. R. J. Mo88 and Co. or on sending his postal address to Mr. Moss.

div.head: CAIRO WATER COMMISSION.
div.p: Now that it is practically an understood thing that the special Water Commission, appointed by the Government to report upon the water of the Rod el Farag wells, have submitted a favourable report to the Authorities, & contemporary proceeds, as indeed it might be expected to proceed, to attempt to destroy confidence in the finding of the Commission by delating upon the dread loss of hair 'which will follow the continued drinking of these waters.

Indeed the whole thing, Commission, report and all is apparently looked upon by the journal in question as a colossal farce, designed by the Government in order to throw dust in the eyes of the public, for it affirms that the Government do not wish to change the water for two reasons ; "the microbes that are found in the Nile waters, and the present financial embarrasment," and it further points out that "both reasons are groundless, for the microbes can be avoided by filtration, and the Government can open credits from its reserve funds."
Really these two last points are important and it is to be hoped that the Government will only make note of them for future reference.

It was quite to be expected that, should the report prove to be of a favourable nature, there would be many wise acres ready and willing to prove that the report was false, but criticism of such a weak and pointless nature was hardly anticipated

div.head: HELOUAN RACES.
div.p: By kind permission of Colonel D A. Macfarlane and Officers, the band of the King's Own Scottish Borderers will perform the following programme of Music at the Helouan Sporting Skye Meeting to be held on the 20th inst. March - El Capitan-Sousa. Polonaise-Chopin.. Selection–The Orchid-Chopin. Humoreske--Dvorak. Selection, The Merry Widow-Lehar.
Valse Leute - Amourense -- Berger. +Selection - The Belle of New York - Kerker.
Two Stép-Arra Wanna - Moret. Intermezzo--Love in Idlenens---Macbeth. Regimental March - Khedivial Anthem, God Bave the King.
A:J. Wilson, Bandmaster.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Moss liner. "Menes" sailed from LiverI pool on Saturday last, and is due here about | the 28th inst., with passengers, mails and general cargo.
The Moss liner "Philie" sailed this morning for Liverpool, with general cargo including | 6,140 bales of cotton..
The Moss liner "Remeses" arrived this morning from Liverpool via Gibraltar, Algiers and Malta with passengers, mails and general cargo.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: Lord and Lady Cromer have been staying last week with, the Earl and Countess of North) brook who entertained a party at Stratton. Their other grests included: the Margnis and Marchioness of Winchester, the Earl of Oaslow, Lord Curzon of Kedleston, Sir Edward Grey, M.P., the Knight of Kerry and Lady FitzGerald, the Hon. Mrs. Guy Baring, Lady Halse, and Mr. and Mrs. Harry Higgins.
The Sultan of Zanzibar 'arrived at Port Said on Friday last by the German East African $ 8.'"Admiral." The Sultan disembarked and made a number of purchases in the town.

- 1. Sir John and Lady "Harrington arrived yesterday at Alexandria by the S.S. "Hohetzollern". The Minister Plenipotiary at the Court of the Emperor Menelik, is on his way to Adis Abeba from England where he was recently married. They went to Cairo by the noon express and are staying at the Semiramis Hotel.

1 The Countess Antoine de Zogheb, wife of the Danish Diplomatic Agent and Consul General at Cairo, with her two daughters arrived at Alexandria to-day from Europe by the Messageries Maritimes steamer and are leaving for Cairo this afternoon.

We regret to announce the death of Count Sizzo-Norie, a brother of the Count of the same name who resides at Alexandria, Count Edouard Sizzo-Noris, & member of an lustrious Austro-Hungarian family, died, at his rooms, No. 4, St. James's-place, 8:W. 00 Friday week'in circumstances which were in. vestigated at the Westminster Coroner's Court on Tuesday last. His death was due to morphia I poisoning, but it is understood that some | letters which he left behind him thron consi. deráble light upon the fatality. The Count's family hold hereditary estates in the Southern | Tyrol. His brother, Count Gustave Sizzo-Noris,

for three years prior to August last was AustroHungarian Vicé-Consul in London, and doring that period, in the absence of his chief, he frequently acted as Consnl-General. On leaving England, he went to Milan ás Consul General. Count Edourd, who was about forty years of age, was a member of the St. James's Clob, and during the past few years wis & frequent visitor to London. Eleven weeks ago he took op his regidence in St. Jaines's place. The jury at the inquest returned verdict of suióide ? during temporary insanity,
Ibrahim Pasba Neguib and Dr. Raffer have returned to Alexandria from Rote, here they attended the International Medical Con gress. Ibrahim Pasha . Neguib has left for Cairo.
George Bey Rini, Inspector of the Khedi | vial Mail S.S. and Graving Docks Company Ltd., arrived here yesterday by the S.S. "Ismailia.
Mr. and Mrs. Henry R. Newman have left Phil and propose to spend the rest of the season on their dahabeah at Abu Simbel.

Lieutenant M. J. Wheatley, the Dorretabire Regiment, has been taken on the strength & the Egyptian Army with the rank of Bimbashi, vice El Bimbashi D. H. Y. Benghongh, deceased. Bimbashi Wheatley is posted to the Sudan Government.
Mr. E. J. Scott has arrived in Cairo, on his return from England.
Mr. William C. Hornblower, Superintendent of the Western Oasis Railway, who has | been in Cairo for the past couple of days, has retarned to Upper Egypt

The following passengers left Cairo yesterday for Upper Egypt by Cook's P.S. PCteopatra" Mr. and Mrs. Antonio Müller, Mr and Mrs. JA. F. Schimidt, Mrs. Carkeet James, Mr. W. Lewin, Mr. and Mrs. J. W. Oddie.

div.head: GRAND HOTEL, HELOU AN.
div.p: The following are staying at the Grand Hotel, Helouan :

Mr: and Mrs. M. de Dobriansky, Mösa ... James, Miss K. H. Mackeller, Mr. C. H. C. Byvanck, Mr. and Mrs. Henry. Willard Denison, Miss Mellersh, Miss Kelly, Mrs. Vallange Condell, Mr. and Mrs. R. Norton, Mr. and Mrs. C. J. Fletcher, Sir Harrington and Lady Simeon, Miss Barker, Major and Mrs. J.H. Grant, Misses F. and A. Magsh, Mr. David Erskine, Mri and Mrs. A. P. Mack, Mrs., Misa and Master Menky, Frau Dr. Friedrich, Herr F. Sohnabel, Mr. and Mrs. P. W. Stone, Mr. and Mme. Serge Ywritainn, Misses A. and K. Monaban, Mrs. Gaussen, Mr. W. Leonard May, Mrs and Master Duodas Orr, Miss M. Smith, Miss Silver, Capt. the Hon. W. Trefuses, Hon. Evelyn Trefuses, Count Constantin, Hari R.Rosenberg, Mr. and Mrs. M. Stephens, Roy.. W. N. B. Cooper, Røv. L. R. Evans, Herri Hans Quandt, Mr. and Mn: U. Dogner, Mrit. Tohdano, Judge Kraft, Mr. J. Cavaly, Mr. B. F. Gesman. Mrs. I. Harvey, Mr. R. Sherard.
| PARIS-HOUSE GENEYA.. Mm. Auberge is exhibiting her mom dels at the Hotel Villa Victoria, Cairo.

row.cell: Alhambra Theatre. Lilliputian Troupe. Benefit Performance for Calabrian Relief Fund. "The Geisha," 9.15 p.m.

Savoy Palace Hotel. Exhibition of Water- Colour Drawings of Egypt and Nubia by Mr. A. O. Laplough, Eiffel Tour. French Theatrical Troupe. San Stefano Casino, Grand Symphony Concert, Ever afternoon at 5.30 p.m
Cinemaphon Axis and Dores, old Ramleh Station, 6.30 and 9.30
Alhambra Theatre. Farewell Perfomance by the Lilliputian troupe. "Fra Diavolo," "La Boheme," "The Geisha," "Elisir d' Amore," "Cavalleria, Rusticans," "La Favorita." 9.15 p.m.
Sailors and Soldiers; Institute Fancy Sale and Christmas Tree. 3 p.m. Alhambra Theatre. Debut of Fregoli,
Pigeon Shooting Champs Elysee 2.30 p.m Alhambra Theatre. Matinee. "Lucia di Lammermoor," 4.
Connaught House. Y.W.C.A. Sale of work at the Semiramis Hotel. Heluan Casino, Fusco's Orchestra. 4 p.m.
The slade Groud, Abbamich. Regimental Sports of the Coldstream Guards.
Helouan Sporting Club. First Race Meeting.
Savoy Hotel, small Dance. Brithish Recreation Club. Christmas Tree. Hotel Carpet Ceremony. 11 a.m.

div.head: CONTRATS, (11h.55 a.m.)
div.p: Cours de la Bourse de Minet-el-Bassal
REMARQUES
Cotons: Nouvelle récolte.—Le novembre a ouvert à 14 15/16 sous l'impression de la clôture d'Amérique et ne tarde même pas à fléchir à 14 7/8, mais il se raffermit de nouveau. Affaires claisemées.
Récolte actuelle. —Juillet a débuté à 14 5/16 et reste soutenu. Marché peu animé.
Grains de coton: Nouvelle récolte.— Sans affaires importante; quand même les cours sont bien tenus.
Récolte actuelle.—Juillet a obtenu P.T. 58 ¾ à l'ouverture.
Fèves-Saidi: Nouvelle récolte.—Marché nul.

div.head: Cheap Prepaid Advertisements
div.p: Under this heading advertisements are inserted at the following rates :—
The address is counted. The advertisement must appear on consecutive days for above rates to be obtained. 50% extra is charged for advertisements not appearing consecutively.

All such advertisements must be prepaid, and to this rule no exception whatever will be made. Letters in reply to advertisements will be posted to any address if a few stamps are sent by the advertiser to cover postage.
